docs.lead_paragraph: Consolidated Edison and its largest union announced a tentative agreement on a contract on Thursday, several hours after Gov.Andrew M. Cuomo intervened personally in their monthlong labor dispute. About 8,000 of the utility's workers had been locked out since July 1. Since then, about 5,000 Con Ed managers and retired workers kept the company's electrical system operating amid hot weather and high demand for air-conditioning.

headline.main: Tentative Deal in Con Ed Labor Dispute

docs.abstract: Consolidated Edison and its largest union announce a tentative contract agreement; move comes within hours of intervention from New York Gov Andrew M Cuomo in the month-long labor lock-out that left 5,000 Con Ed managers and retired workers keeping the company's electrical systems in New York City operating amid hot weather and high demand for air-conditioning. Photo (M)

headline.main: Comparing Medicare and Employer Health Insurance

docs.abstract: People with Medicare are more satisfied with their health care than people with employer-based insurance.
docs.snippet: People with Medicare are more satisfied with their health care than people with employer-based insurance.

headline.main: Con Ed and Union Reach Contract Agreement
headline.print_headline: Tentative Deal in Con Ed Labor Dispute

docs.abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo intervened as a potentially damaging storm approached Con Ed's service area, leading to a deal for locked-out workers to help with storm preparations and repairs. That was soon followed by agreement on a new pact.
docs.snippet: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo intervened as a potentially damaging storm approached Con Ed's service area, leading to a deal for locked-out workers to help with storm preparations and repairs. That was soon followed by agreement on a new pact.

byline.original: By JAMES BARRON and ERIC P. NEWCOMER

headline.main: Children of Gay Federal Workers May Receive Health Coverage

docs.abstract: A proposed rule would extend health benefits to the children of gay individuals partnered with federal employees. But the same-sex partners would still be ineligible given the law that defines marriage as between one man and one woman.
docs.snippet: A proposed rule would extend health benefits to the children of gay individuals partnered with federal employees. But the same-sex partners would still be ineligible given the law that defines marriage as between one man and one woman.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new joint effort between government agencies and private companies will bear down on health care fraud by sharing and comparing claims data.

headline.seo: Obama and Insurers Join to Cut Health Care Fraud
headline.main: Obama and Insurers Join to Cut Health Care Fraud
headline.print_headline: Obama and Insurers Join To Cut Health Care Fraud

docs.abstract: Pres Obama and health insurance executives plan to announce a new joint effort to crack down on health care fraud by sharing and comparing claims data; collaboration represents a turnabout for the president, who has often denounced abuses by the insurance industry.
docs.snippet: A new joint effort between government agencies and private companies will bear down on health care fraud by sharing and comparing claims data.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama wrapped up a three-day fund-raising swing with an emotional defense of his efforts to make higher education more affordable and to expand access to health care.

headline.main: Obama Delivers Defense of His Policy Efforts
headline.print_headline: Obama Delivers Defense of His Policy Efforts

docs.abstract: Pres Obama, appearing at the National Urban League in New Orleans, La, issues a robust defense of his efforts to make higher education more affordable, to increase training programs for young people and to expand access to health care.
docs.snippet: President Obama wrapped up a three-day fund-raising swing with an emotional defense of his efforts to make higher education more affordable and to expand access to health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: The study reflects an effort to sidestep difficulty in gauging the health effects of covering more people, and comes as states consider expanding Medicaid under the health care law.

headline.seo: Medicaid Expansion May Lower Death Rate, Study Says
headline.main: Medicaid Expansion May Lower Death Rates, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Medicaid Expansion May Lower Death Rates, Study Says

docs.abstract: Harvard study published in The New England Journal of Medicine finds that state expansion of Medicaid programs results in a lower number of overall deaths; study comes as states are deciding whether to expand Medicaid by 2014 under the Affordable Care Act, in accordance with the Supreme Court's ruling on the law.
docs.snippet: The study reflects an effort to sidestep difficulty in gauging the health effects of covering more people, and comes as states consider expanding Medicaid under the health care law.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the Congressional Budget Office's new cost estimates for the law overhauling health care misstated the projected net costs of the law's insurance coverage provisions over the 11 years from 2012 through 2022. The new estimate is $1.168 trillion, not billion; the previous estimate, before a ruling by the Supreme Court limiting an expansion of Medicaid, was $1.252 trillion, not billion.
